replies.bodyText:
I don't think we should be supporting this.
Allowing this means that we are in a way calling this function and evaluating the expression at compile-time, which we do not do for function calls.
The static type of 'xml:createText(...) at compile-time is always 'xml:Text. So if the user wants to do this they have to say
xml<never> b = <xml<never>> 'xml:createText("");

replies.bodyText: The spec doesn't talk about sub types of xml:Text being implicitly castable to string right?
replies.author: suleka96

replies.bodyText:
Whatever works for T should generally work for subtypes of T too.
So since xml<never> is a subtype of xml:Text and xml:Text can be implicitly converted to string, xml<never> should be implicitly converted to string.
The spec also explicitly mentions the empty xml value under "Casting and conversion"

If a value of type xml:Text is the empty xml value, then it is implicitly converted to the empty string; otherwise the value is implicitly converted to a string that has a constituent character for each singleton item in the xml:Text sequence.
